awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Standard: Exploring how scientists on multidisciplinary laboratory teams negotiate expertise and claim legitimacy regarding ethical practice.
awd_abstract_narration:
The increasing diversity and complexity characterizing today's engineering workforce and practice requires new research on the social factors that shape ethics in STEM work. A common approach in research and teaching is to incorporate the social aspects of teamwork, diversity, and ethics into isolated lectures, separate courses, or to treat them as outcome variables. However, this project takes the perspective that ethics is interwoven into everyday STEM work not as a static outcome variable, but rather as a communication-based achievement enacted in the social processes through which STEM work is organized. It tests the hypothesis that in addition to technical, process, or industry expertise, STEM team members can cultivate ethical expertise, a form of knowledge and skills informing appropriate ways of working that is developed through situated experience. This research advances scientific knowledge by systematically investigating if and how different patterns of communication affect ethical climates and ethical behavior within vertically integrated multidisciplinary STEM teams from national and university laboratories. It identifies areas in which misperceptions or misapplication of expertise may act as a barrier to the development of ethical cultures in STEM organizations and explores the ways ethics are learned and shared through ongoing social relationships and interactions. Identifying the social and communicative factors impacting the ethical accomplishment of complex scientific work provides insight into a variety of actions and policies that universities, national labs, and industry partners can use to cultivate ethical and collaborative research climates to aid in the discovery and application of scientific knowledge. 

The study combines interview and ethnographic data with social network analysis to examine how different patterns of communication and interaction among members of STEM teams affect their perceptions of ethics in laboratories and how these perceptions impact ethical research climates and the social structures that enable effective and ethical teamwork. Phase 1 utilizes ethnographic methods and grounded thematic analysis of interviews and observations to capture and investigate the everyday practice of participants. Phase 2 builds upon these findings and employs social network analysis to assess the interdependent relationships between the different forms of expertise present in the development of ethical climates, and their relationship to ongoing interactions among team members. Phase 3 integrates these findings and maps them onto extant literature to compare the salient features of each institution and determine the explanatory mechanisms for the cultivation of ethical climates and ethical behavior in STEM teams.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project was to systematically investigate the relationship between various communication processes and the development of ethical climates in multidisciplinary STEM research teams. Specifically, we sought to identify what forms of communication and work practices are associated with researchers’ claims to expertise and whether these claims are viewed as valid and legitimate by other group members. To accomplish this goal we employed multiple qualitative research methods – interviews with researchers, observations of laboratory meetings, and shadowing of individuals engaged in work – to study the activities of three different university or national research groups. 

We identified multiple interrelated themes regarding the different ways that scientists enacted expertise or attributed expertise to others. First, the work of scientists was heavily influenced by access to, and operation of, complex technologies. To be successful scientists needed to have time with exclusive scientific tools, develop knowledge to address inevitable emergent technology failures, and exhibit a willingness to persevere through ongoing failure. Lab members noted that much of the knowledge they applied in conducting work had little to do with fundamental scientific knowledge they would have learned in classes or formal training. Second, despite working in a group laboratory environment, scientists viewed their work as largely independent. Although scientists were reliant on group members with different forms of knowledge to gain access to, and operate, necessary tools and spaces (i.e., physicists worked with engineers to develop and use lasers) goals were most often expressed in individual and not collective terms. Third, the situated and emergent nature of problem-solving limited opportunities for knowledge sharing and group learning. Problems often needed to be addressed immediately to continue work, and because work was viewed as both idiosyncratic and individualistic, there was little perceived benefit or incentive to share solutions with others.

These findings can inform STEM education and training by highlighting the ways learning occurs through interactions that take place during active scientific work. This indicates the benefits of increasing opportunities for scientists to observe others as they conduct various tasks. The results demonstrate the value of making communication among lab members a regular, explicit, and important aspect of work. This research also points to value of scientific teams and groups explicitly reflecting upon everyday obstacles and failures as opposed to focusing group discussions on accomplishments and future-oriented tasks.

In terms of products and dissemination of results, the findings of this research were shared with both communication and engineering scholarly communities. Specifically, four different papers were presented at communication conferences and three different papers presented at engineering conferences. These manuscripts will be submitted for publication in relevant scholarly journals with the intention of reaching a broad audience in both the social sciences and STEM fields.
